Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar 2016" that will be held on October 15 and 16, 2016, on the campus of the University of Wyoming.

This conference is the twenty-fourth installment of the West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar (WCOAS), a series that annually brings together a diverse group of mathematicians whose primary research interests are in the theory of operator algebras. Some of the foci of the 2016 event are the following: the Elliott classification program for C*-algebras; the Baum-Connes conjecture and its applications; rigidity for actions of countable discrete groups on von Neumann algebras; subfactors and their invariants; graph C*-algebras; free probability and its applications; quantum groups; crossed products, imprimitivity, and duality for C*-algebras. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work. The seminar website is located at http://www.uwyo.edu/zniu/wcoas2016/index.html.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 24th West Coast Operator Seminar starts at 8:30 am on the Saturday, October 15, 2016, and finishes at the noon of the Sunday, October 16, 2016. There are 11 lectures:

  1. K-theory of group Banach *algebras and group actions. Guoliang Yu (Texas A&M).
  2. Wavelets and spectral triples for fractal representations of Cuntz algebras. Judith Packer (CU, Boulder).
  3. Cuntz-Pimsner algebras from group actions. Valentin Deaconu (University of Nevada, Reno).
  4. Twisted spectral triples and the Chern-Gauss-Bonnet theorem for C*-dynamical systems. Farzad Fathizadeh (Caltech)
  5. Subfactors and Tensor Categories. Hans Wenzl (UC, San Diego).
  6. Cocycle and orbit equivalence superrigidity for coinduced actions. Daniel Drimbe (UC, San Diego).
  7. On noncommutative distributional symmetries and de Finetti theorems associated with them. Weihua Liu (Indiana University).
  8. An alternating moment condition for bi-free independence. Ian Charlesworth (UCLA).
  9. Classification and invariants for inductive limit C*-algebras. Guihua Gong (University of Puerto Rico).
  10. Automorphisms with the Rohlin property on nuclear C*-algebras. Yasuhiko Sato (Kyoto University).
  11. A self-absorbing action on the Jiang-Su algebra. Qingyun Wang (University of Oregon).

Among the speakers, there are two Ph.D. students, three postdoctoral fellows, one assistant professor, five professors.

The following is the detailed schedule of the conference:

Saturday

  • 8:30 -- 9:10: Guoliang Yu, K-theory of group Banach * algebras and group actions
  • 9:20 -- 10:00: Judith Packer, Wavelets and spectral triples for fractal representations of Cuntz algebras
  • 10:00--10:30: Coffee Break
  • 10:30--11:10: Valentin Deaconu, Cuntz-Pimsner algebras from group actions
  • 11:20--12:00: Farzad Fathizadeh, Twisted spectral triples and the Chern-Gauss-Bonnet theorem for C*-dynamical systems
  • 12:00--13:30: Lunch
  • 13:30--14:10: Hans Wenzl, Subfactors and Tensor Categories
  • 14:20--15:00: Daniel Drimbe, Cocycle and orbit equivalence superrigidity for coinduced actions
  • 15:00--15:30: Coffee Break
  • 15:30--16:10: Weihua Liu, On noncommutative distributional symmetries and de Finetti theorems associated with them
  • 16:20--17:00: Ian Charlesworth, An alternating moment condition for bi-free independence
  • 18:30: Conference Dinner

Sunday

  • 8:30--9:10: Guihua Gong, Classification and invariants for inductive limit C*-algebras
  • 9:20--10:00: Yasuhiko Sato, Automorphisms with the Rohlin property on nuclear C*-algebras
  • 10:10--10:50: Qingyun Wang, A self-absorbing action on the Jiang-Su algebra

The results in the following papers are at least partially based on the authors' work during the conference:

  • Ping Wong Ng, Nonstable absorption, preprint.
  • Ping Wong Ng, Purely infinite corona algebras, and extensions, preprint.
  • Marc Rieffel, Vector bundles for "Matrix algebras converge to the sphere", arXiv:1711.04054.

In total, the conference has 32 participants, and half of them are younger researchers (1 undergraduare student, 8 Ph.D. students, 7 Postdoctoral Fellows). Mixing with well-established mathematicians provides them a unique opportunity to disseminate their results and stay abreast of the current work in the subject.

The list of participants and the abstracts of the talks can be found at the conference website (http://www.uwyo.edu/zniu/wcoas2016).

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2018
Modified by: Zhuang Niu
